results.title: The Black man and his bride
results.creator_credit: Tim Burstall, Patrick Ryan and Eltham Films
results.brief_description: By using camera movement and editing technique the film animates the series of paintings “The Black Man and his Bride”, by Arthur Boyd. Tim Burstall also wrote the original ballad sung to guitar accompaniment which runs for the duration of the film sung by Donald Ayrton.

results.title: Bark canoe
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Alcheringa”.
Shows the methods of canoe manufacture employed by some Australian First Nations peoples. Illustrates the removal of bark from a tree in a single section, its shaping and testing, and finally the canoe’s use for fishing. Introduced by Bill Onus.

results.title: My colour, your kind
results.brief_description: A young girl, incarcerated in a dormitory, escapes to her rightful place in the world. During the journey she recollects her life and the treatment she has endured. In My Colour, Your Kind director Danielle Mclean uses her experience as a fair skinned First Nations person to explore the notion of First Nations identity.

results.title: A Postcard from Ovens
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Jack Keane and ACMI Content Development
results.brief_description: An edited excerpt from ‘Working Holiday’ (1957) produced by Jack Keane for the Victorian Department of Agriculture. Shows hop picking in Victoria where seasonal workers gather from all parts of Australia for six weeks to harvest hops in the rich Ovens Valley. The weekend breaks are spent swimming, fishing or sight-seeing in the surrounding Alps.

results.title: Op shops of our town
results.brief_description: An amusing ‘mockumentary’ on several of the Op Shops in the East Gippsland region. This tongue-in-cheek journey introduces us to the eccentricities of op-shopping, the people who run them, the people who shop in them, and the eclectic mix of goods found in them. Stars Mr Kearney and Ms Jennian, with thanks to the following participating Op Shops - Paynesville Op Shop and Uniting Church, Lakes Entrance Ambulance, Salvos and St Vincents in Bairnsdale. Music from the fabulous Stereophonic Optigan, written and played by Mr Kearney. Camera - Jeremy Johnson.

results.title: Old man: returning to Lake Condah Mission

video_links.name: Old man: returning to Lake Condah Mission

results.brief_description: This is a documentary film about growing up on Lake Condah Aboriginal Mission. A local Elder, Uncle Kenny Saunders, visits the site of Lake Condah Mission and talks about his childhood memories revealing a past of cruelty and fear, and the devastation felt in the aftermath of the Eumerella massacres.

results.title: Dispensing a cure
results.brief_description: One of 6 works created in 2003 by community artist Malcolm McKinnon specifically for the MAP project. Each of the works focuses on a different aspect of memory and identity in the Wimmera/Mallee region. Ian Darling and Doug McColl have each practised pharmacy for over forty years in the Warracknabeal district. In this film they recall the era when most drugs were hand-made on the premises, generally from raw materials. Ian also tells of the mysterious medicine jar labelled ‘ADT’ and of an old-fashioned coin-operated machine for a self administered electric shock.

results.title: Narrapumelap
results.brief_description: Narrapumelap - A woman looks at footage of herself as a young girl exploring a graceful old homestead and reflects on how it captures the magical nature of the place and its profound resonance in her memory.

results.title: Daylight saving sleep schedule
results.brief_description: They say it takes a village, and the village it seems has moved online, with countless parental bloggers dishing out advice for desperate parents - many of whom are exceptionally sleep deprived. @jampikelets offers a moment of reprieve, with his hilariously honest posts making light of the early years of baby raising. And there is nothing more daunting than a daylight savings transition to unnerve parents everywhere. 4am start anyone?
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

They say it takes a village and the village its seems has moved online, with countless parental bloggers dishing out advice for desperate parents - many of whom are exceptionally sleep deprived. @jampikelets offers a moment reprieve, with his hilariously honest posts making light of the early years of baby raising. And there is nothing more daunting than a daylight savings transition to unnerve parents everywhere. 4am start anyone?

And there is nothing more daunting than a daylight savings transition to unnerve parents everywhere. 4am start anyone?

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Money movement mindset
results.brief_description: Annoying finance bros beware: the comedians are coming for your grindset! Financial planning is a popular podcast and video genre online — but many of them are hosted by young men whose views on how to make bank can be hilariously macho, and based on an unrealistic picture of how and why most people spend their money. In this video, Tiktok comedian Caroline Baniewicz skewers finance bro culture, satirising the impractical ways that these podcasters advise on making your first million.
results.description: Annoying finance bros beware: the comedians are coming for your grindset! Financial planning is a popular podcast and video genre online — many of them hosted by young men whose views on how to make bank can be hilariously macho and out of touch. In this video, Tiktok comedian Caroline Baniewicz skewers finance bro culture, satirising the impractical ways that these podcasters advise on making your first million.
